<<<api>>>: InputStream.read
<<<code>>>: You can use the read() method of the InputStream to read the file line by line and count the number of characters, words, and lines. Here's an example code:
```java
public class Document {
    private InputStream inputStream;
    private int lineCount = 0;
    private int wordCount = 0;
    private int charCount = 0;

    public Document(String documentName) throws FileNotFoundException {
        inputStream = new FileInputStream(documentName);
    }

    public int getLineCount() {
        return lineCount;
    }

    public int getWordCount() {
        return wordCount;
    }

    public int getCharCount() {
        return charCount;
    }

    public void readFile() throws IOException {
        BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(inputStream));
        String line;
        while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
            lineCount++;
            charCount += line.length();
            StringTokenizer tokenizer = new StringTokenizer(line, " ");
            while (tokenizer.hasMoreTokens()) {
                wordCount++;
            }
        }
        inputStream.close();
    }
}
```
You can then create an instance of the Document class and call the readFile() method to read the file and get the count of lines, words, and characters.

<<<explanation>>>: The read() method reads the file line by line and returns the next line as a string. You can then use the StringTokenizer class to split each line into words and count the number of words. The line count is simply the number of lines read. The word count is the number of words in each line, and the character count is the sum of the lengths of all the lines read.
